subsection.title: Reading Function Values from a Graph
subsection.p: The Dow-Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) gives the average of the stock prices of 30 major companies. The graph in shows the DJIA as a function of time during the stock market correction of October 1987. The DJIA is thus f(t), recorded at noon on day t of October.

The values of the input variable, time, are displayed on the horizontal axis, and the values of the output variable, DJIA, are displayed on the vertical axis. There is no formula that gives the DJIA for a particular day; but it is still a function, defined by its graph. The value of f(t) is specified by the vertical coordinate of the point with the given t-coordinate.

ol.label: a
ol.li: The coordinates of point P in are (15, 2412). What do the coordinates tell you about the function f?
If the DJIA was 1726 at noon on October 20, what can you say about the graph of f?

ol.label: a
ol.li: The coordinates of point P tell us that f(15) = 2412, so the DJIA was 2412 at noon on October 15.
We can say that f(20) = 1726, so the point (20, 1726) lies on the graph of f. This point is labeled Q in .

subsection.p: Thus, the coordinates of each point on the graph of the function represent a pair of corresponding values of the two variables.

assemblage.title: Graph of a Function
assemblage.p: The point (a, b) lies on the graph of the function f if and only if f(a)=b.

statement.p: The water level in Lake Huron alters unpredictably over time. The graph in gives the average water level, L(t), in meters in the year t over a 20-year period. (Source: The Canadian Hydrographic Service)

image.description: graph of Lake Huron water level

li.p: The coordinates of point H in are (1997, 176.98). What do the coordinates tell you about the function L?
The average water level in 2004 was 176.11 meters. Write this fact in function notation. What can you say about the graph of L?
L(1997) = 176.98; the average water level was 176.98 meters in 1997.
L(2004) = 176.11. The point (2004, 176.11) lies on the graph of L.

subsection.p: Another way of describing how a graph depicts a function is as follows:

assemblage.title: Functions and Coordinates
assemblage.p: Each point on the graph of the function f has coordinates (x, f (x)) for some value of x.

statement.p:
shows the graph of a function g.
Find g(-2) and g(5).
For what value(s) of t is g(t) = -2?
What is the largest, or maximum, value of g(t)? For what value of t does the function take on its maximum value?
On what intervals is g increasing?

ol.label: a
ol.li: To find g(-2), we look for the point with t-coordinate -2. The point (-2, 0) lies on the graph of g, so g(-2) = 0. Similarly, the point (5, 1) lies on the graph, so g(5) = 1.

We look for points on the graph with y-coordinate -2. Because the points (-5, -2), (-3, -2), and (3, -2) lie on the graph, we know that g(-5) = -2, g(-3) = -2, and g(3) = -2. Thus, the t-values we want are -5, -3, and 3.
The highest point on the graph is (1, 4), so the largest y-value is 4. Thus, the maximum value of g(t) is 4, and it occurs when t = 1.

A graph is increasing if the y-values get larger as we read from left to right. The graph of g is increasing for t-values between -4 and 1, and between 3 and 5. Thus, g is increasing on the intervals (-4, 1) and (3, 5).

statement.p:
Refer to the graph of the function g shown in in .
Find g(0).
For what value(s) of t is g(t) = 0?
What is the smallest, or minimum, value of g(t)? For what value of t does the function take on its minimum value?
On what intervals is g decreasing?

technology.title: Finding Coordinates with a Graphing Calculator
technology.p: We can use the TRACE feature of the calculator to find the coordinates of points on a graph. For example, graph the equation y = -2.6x - 5.4 in the window

Press TRACE, and a “bug” begins flashing on the display. The coordinates of the bug appear at the bottom of the display, as shown in . Use the left and right arrows to move the bug along the graph. You can check that the coordinates of the point (2, -10.6) do satisfy the equation y = -2.6x - 5.4.

The points identified by the Trace bug depend on the window settings and on the type of calculator. If we want to find the y-coordinate for a particular x-value, we enter the x-coordinate of the desired point and press ENTER.

subsection.title: Constructing the Graph of a Function
subsection.p: Although some functions are defined by their graphs, we can also construct graphs for functions described by tables or equations. We make these graphs the same way we graph equations in two variables: by plotting points whose coordinates satisfy the equation.

solution.p: Choose several convenient values for x and evaluate the function to find the corresponding f(x)-values. For this function we cannot choose x-values less than -4, because the square root of a negative number is not a real number. f(\alert{-4}) =\sqrt{\alert{-4} + 4}=\sqrt{0}= 0 f(\alert{-3}) =\sqrt{\alert{-3} + 4}=\sqrt{1}= 1 f(\alert{0}) =\sqrt{\alert{0} + 4}=\sqrt{4}=2 f(\alert{2}) =\sqrt{\alert{2} + 4}=\sqrt{6}\approx 2.45 f(\alert{5}) =\sqrt{\alert{5} + 4}=\sqrt{9}=3 The results are shown in the table.

technology.title: Using a Calculator to Graph a Function
technology.p: We can also use a graphing calculator to obtain a table and graph for the function in . We graph a function just as we graphed an equation. For this function, we enter Y_1 = \sqrt{\,}(X+4) and press ZOOM 6 for the standard window. The calculator's graph is shown in .

li.p: Complete the table of values and sketch a graph of the function.
Use your calculator to make a table of values and graph the function.

subsection.title: Graphical Solution of Equations and Inequalities
subsection.p: The graph of an equation in two variables is just a picture of its solutions. When we read the coordinates of a point on the graph, we are reading a pair of x- and y-values that make the equation true.

paragraphs.p: For example, the point (2, 7) lies on the graph of y = 2x + 3 shown in , so we know that the ordered pair (2, 7) is a solution of the equation y = 2x + 3. You can verify algebraically that x = \alert{2} and y = \alert{7} satisfy the equation: \text{Does }~\alert{7} = 2 (\alert{2}) + 3\text{?} ~~ \alert{Yes}

subsection.p: We can also say that x = 2 is a solution of the one-variable equation 2x + 3 = 7. In fact, we can use the graph of y = 2x + 3 to solve the equation 2x + 3 = k for any value of k. Thus, we can use graphs to find solutions to equations in one variable.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = 285 - 15x to solve the equation 150 = 285 - 15x.

sidebyside.p: Begin by locating the point P on the graph for which y = 150, as shown in . Now find the x-coordinate of point P by drawing an imaginary line from P straight down to the x-axis. The x-coordinate of P is x = 9. Thus, P is the point (9,150), and x = 9 when y = 150. The solution of the equation 150 = 285 - 15x is x = 9.

solution.p: You can verify the solution algebraically by substituting x = \alert{9} into the equation:

note.p:
The relationship between an equation and its graph is an important one. For the previous example, make sure you understand that the following three statements are equivalent:
The point (9, 150) lies on the graph of y = 285 - 15x.
The ordered pair (9, 150) is a solution of the equation y = 285 - 15x.
x = 9 is a solution of the equation 150 = 285 - 15x.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Use the graph of y = 30 - 8x shown in to solve the equation 30 - 8x = 50

subsection.p: In a similar fashion, we can solve inequalities with a graph.

paragraphs.p: Consider again the graph of y = 2x + 3, shown in . We saw that x = 2 is the solution of the equation 2x + 3 = 7. When we use x = 2 as the input for the function f(x) = 2x + 3, the output is y = 7. Which input values for x produce output values greater than 7?

You can see in that x-values greater than 2 produce y-values greater than 7, because points on the graph with x-values greater than 2 have y-values greater than 7. Thus, the solutions of the inequality 2x + 3 \gt 7 are x\gt 2. You can verify this result by solving the inequality algebraically.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = 285 - 15x to solve the inequality 285 - 15x \gt 150

solution.p: We begin by locating the point P on the graph for which y = 150 and x = 9 (its x-coordinate). Now, because y = 285 - 15x for points on the graph, we are looking for points on the graph with y-coordinate greater than 150. These points are shown in . The x-coordinates of these points are the x-values that satisfy the inequality. From the graph, we see that the solutions are x \lt 9.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Use the graph of y = 30 - 8x in to solve the inequality 30 - 8x \le 50

subsection.p: We can also use this graphical technique to solve nonlinear equations and inequalities.

statement.p: Use a graph of f(x) = -2x^3 + x^2 + 16x to solve the equation -2x^3 + x^2 + 16x = 15

solution.p: If we sketch in the horizontal line y = 15, we can see that there are three points on the graph of f that have y-coordinate 15, as shown in . The x-coordinates of these points are the solutions of the equation.
From the graph, we see that the solutions are x = -3, x = 1, and approximately x = 2.5. We can verify each solution algebraically.

For example, if x = \alert{-3}, we have \begin{align*} f(\alert{-3})\amp -2(\alert{-3})3 + (\alert{-3})^2 + 16(\alert{-3})\\ \amp= -2(-27) + 9 - 48\\ \amp =54 + 9 - 48 = 15 \end{align*} so -3 is a solution. Similarly, you can check that x = 1 and x = 2.5 are solutions.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 shown in to solve \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 = 6 and verify your solutions algebraically.

technology.title: Using the Trace Feature
technology.p: You can use the Trace feature on a graphing calculator to approximate solutions to equations. Graph the function f(x) in in the window

Xmin=-4
Xmax=4
Ymin=-20
Ymax=40
and trace along the curve to the point (2.4680851, 15.512401). We are close to a solution, because the y-value is close to 15. Try entering x-values close to 2.4680851, for instance, x = 2.4 and x = 2.5, to find a better approximation for the solution.
We can use the intersect feature on a graphing calculator to obtain more accurate estimates for the solutions of equations.

statement.p: Use the graph in to solve the inequality -2x^3 + x^2 + 16x \ge 15

solution.p: We first locate all points on the graph that have y-coordinates greater than or equal to 15. The x-coordinates of these points are the solutions of the inequality.
shows the points in red, and their x-coordinates as intervals on the x-axis. The solutions are x \le -3 and 1\le x \le 2.5, or in interval notation, (-\infty, -3] \cup [1, 2.5].

statement.p: Use in to solve the inequality \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 \lt 6
